user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCONF) && \
  (defined(HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU) || defined(HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF))
  long value = -1;
#ifdef HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU
  if (0 >= value)
    value = sysconf (_SC_CRAY_NCPU);
#endif /* HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU */
#ifdef HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF
  if (0 >= value)
    value = sysconf (_SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF);
#endif /* HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF */
  if (0 >= value)
    return -1;
  ret = (int) value;
  if ((long) ret != value)
    return -1; /* Overflow */
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCONF &&
          (HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU || HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF) */
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_:
#define HAVE_SYSCONF 1
...
#define HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments: The function mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_ has no parameters (it is defined with void), so MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified) is not applicable. All assignments in the function target local variables (value and ret), not parameters. The sysconf() call takes an integer macro constant (e.g. _SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF) and returns a long; these macros are not function parameters and the returned value is stored in a local variable. The code performs an explicit overflow check before casting the long to int. There are no pointer parameters, no pointer modifications, and no other function parameters anywhere in the fragment, so there are no code locations that need further investigation for Rule 17.8.
